title: 106_hr2240
content: The Act titled "Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999" includes an adjustment to per beneficiary limits. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 includes adjustments to payment amounts to agencies with limits under the national average. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 adjusts payment limits for providers based on median values, with varying percentages for different fiscal years. Additionally, a per beneficiary cap is established with the option for waiver. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 adjusts payment limits for providers based on median values, with varying percentages for different fiscal years. U.S.C. 1395x(v)(1)(L) is further amended to set payment limits for providers with a 12-month cost reporting period ending in fiscal year 1994. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 adjusts payment limits for providers based on median values, with varying percentages for different fiscal years. Providers specializing in treating costly individuals may receive higher payments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with appropriate organizations. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 adjusts payment limits for providers based on median values, with varying percentages for different fiscal years. Services must consult with relevant organizations to determine criteria for special payment provisions under specific clauses of the Social Security Act. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 adjusts payment limits for providers based on median values. A new clause allows providers to receive payment exceeding limits for home health services if the cost significantly exceeds the limit due to unusual variations in necessary care for the individual. The Secretary will establish criteria for such payments. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 allows providers to apply for payment exceeding limits if costs significantly exceed the limit due to necessary care variations. The Secretary will use provider data to make determinations and providers can elect to receive payment quarterly. The amendment takes effect six months after enactment and applies to applications for payment of reasonable costs for outliers. The Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999 allows providers to request special payments if costs exceed limits due to necessary care variations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit reports to Congress one year and three years after the enactment of the Act, detailing the impact of these special payment provisions on home health agencies. The report to Congress updates information on illnesses and characteristics of patients receiving special payments under the Medicare Home Health Access Restoration Act of 1999, as well as characteristics of home health agencies providing services to these patients. SEC. 3. REVISION OF PER VISIT LIMITS. Amends Section 1861(v)(1)(L)(i) of the Social Security Act to adjust payment limits before October 1, 1999. Adds a new subclause setting the limit at 110 percent of the median. SEC. 4. ELIMINATION OF CONTINGENT 15 PERCENT REDUCTION IN PAYMENT LIMITS UNDER THE INTERIM PAYMENT SYSTEM. Section 4603 of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended by striking subsection (e). This relates to informational materials for Medicare beneficiaries regarding home health services. The Secretary is required to prepare a notice of appeal rights for Medicare beneficiaries regarding coverage determinations. Home health agencies must provide this notice to individuals upon discharge. Physicians will receive guidance to assist affected individuals, especially those whose home health services are discontinued prematurely. The Secretary must provide materials to home health agencies for compliance with Medicare regulations. Additional resources may be requested, and distribution of necessary information to agencies must begin within six months of the Act's enactment. Home health agencies and physicians providing services under the Medicare program are required to receive information prepared under this section. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the Medicare home health benefit. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the relationship between costs of Medicare home health services and services provided by other agencies and facilities, to determine potential savings for the Medicare program. The Comptroller General will determine if including home health services in the Medicare program has reduced overall costs to the Federal government. A report on the study's results must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
